original: Arnoldsson, Hans Fritiof, leg. läk., Göteborg, f. 3/10/09’ i Fjällbacka, Gbgs o. Boh. 1, av sjökapt. Arnold Andersson o. Agnes Magnusson. G. 42 m. Elisabeth Arboe. Barn: Inger f, 43, Ann 46, Elisabeth 47. — Stud :’ex. i Gbg 30, med. kand. 33 o. med. lic. 38 i Sthlm. Kort. förordn, s. prov:-läk. i Fastnäs distr. 37, i Rimbo, Ramsbergs o. ödeshögs distr. 38, s. skeppsläk. på M/S Uruguay, assist :-läk. v. S:t Eriks sjukh. i Stblm med. avd. 38. Undiläk. v. samma avd. 39- 41, v. Vasa sjukh. i G’bg 41-42, v. Sählgr. sjukh. i Gbg med. avd. sed. 42. Bitr. öv:läk. v. samma avd. fr. 46. Chefläk. f. SvRK hj :exp. t. tyska konc:iäg. 45, f. sv. hj :arb. i Berlin våren 46, chef f. hj :arb. i Österr. höst. 46. Skr.: en del med. upps., Natt o. dimma (skildr. av de tyska konc-.lägren). OffBLeopO, RDDO, RFrHL, Ordre de la Sante Publique, DFrK, Holk Pro Merito, Finska Pro benign. hum., M. de la Reconnaiss. Frang., SvRKftjM, DRKftjM, NRKftjM.
translated: Arnoldsson, Hans Fritiof, licensed doctor, Gothenburg, born October 3rd, 1909 in Fjällbacka, Gothenburg and Bohuslän County. Son of Captain Arnold Andersson and Agnes Magnusson. Married 1942 to Elisabeth Arboe. Children: Inger born in 1943, Ann in 1946, and Elisabeth in 1947. Studied for high school diploma in Gothenburg in 1930, earned Bachelor of Medicine degree in 1933 and Doctor of Medicine degree in 1938 in Stockholm. Short-term positions as a probationary doctor in Fastnäs district in 1937, in Rimbo, Ramsberg, and Ödeshög districts in 1938, as a ship's doctor on M/S Uruguay, and as assistant doctor at S:t Eriks Hospital in Stockholm medical department in 1938. Assistant doctor at the same department from 1939-1941, at Vasa Hospital in Gothenburg from 1941-1942 and at Sählgr. Hospital in Gothenburg medical department since 1942. Deputy senior physician at the same department from 1946. Chief physician for Swedish Red Cross expeditions to German concentration camps in 1945, for Swedish labor in Berlin in the spring of 1946, and chief for labor in Austria in the fall of 1946. Wrote some medical essays and a book called "Natt Och Dimma" (Night and Fog) about the German concentration camps. Has been honored with Officier de L'Ordre de Léopold (Belgium), Royal Order of the Dragon (Romania), Royal Patriotic Society Medal in gold, Order of Public Health (France), Officer's Cross of the Order of Merit (German Federal Republic), Holk's Medal Pro Merito, Finnish Order of the White Rose, Medal of recognition from the French government, Knight of the Swedish Red Cross, Knight of the Danish Red Cross, and Knight of the Norwegian Red Cross.

structured.name: Hans Fritiof Arnoldsson
structured.description: Hans Fritiof Arnoldsson was a licensed doctor in Gothenburg, born on October 3rd, 1909, in Fjällbacka, Gothenburg and Bohuslän County, Sweden. He studied at Gothenburg High School and Karolinska Institute, where he earned a Bachelor of Medicine degree in 1933 and a Doctor of Medicine degree in 1938. He held multiple short-term positions as a probationary doctor and assistant doctor, including at S:t Eriks Hospital in Stockholm medical department and Vasa Hospital in Gothenburg. He later became the chief physician for Swedish Red Cross expeditions to German concentration camps and for Swedish labor in Berlin and Austria. He wrote medical essays and a book called 'Natt Och Dimma' (Night and Fog) about the German concentration camps. Arnoldsson received several honors for his work, including Officier de L'Ordre de Léopold (Belgium), the Royal Order of the Dragon (Romania), the Royal Patriotic Society Medal in gold, the Order of Public Health (France), the Officer's Cross of the Order of Merit (German Federal Republic), Holk's Medal Pro Merito, the Finnish Order of the White Rose, and the Medal of recognition from the French government.
